A **shrieker**, F, is a type of [monster](/wiki/Monster "Monster") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. The shrieker is a type of [fungus](/wiki/Fungus "Fungus") that is one of the few monsters to lack an attack of any kind, including a [passive attack](/wiki/Passive_attack "Passive attack") (even those that trigger on death, as with the [gas spore](/wiki/Gas_spore "Gas spore")).

In lieu of attacking, a shrieker will shriek intermittently when adjacent to the [hero](/wiki/Hero "Hero") or to a monster attacking them, which can [aggravate](/wiki/Aggravate "Aggravate") and wake up monsters and interrupts any [occupation](/wiki/Occupation "Occupation"):[\[1\]](#cite_note-1) the shriek has an additional 1⁄10 chance of summoning a monster on the level, which has a 1⁄13 chance of being a [purple worm](/wiki/Purple_worm "Purple worm") and will otherwise be a random monster appropriate for the level.[\[2\]](#cite_note-2) Shrieking does not use up a turn.

[Eating](/wiki/Eating "Eating") a shrieker [corpse](/wiki/Corpse "Corpse") or [tin](/wiki/Tin "Tin") has a 1⁄5 chance (20%) of granting [poison resistance](/wiki/Poison_resistance "Poison resistance").

[Chatting](/wiki/Chatting "Chatting") with a shrieker will also cause it to shriek, which aggravates monsters but cannot summon any.[\[3\]](#cite_note-3)

Purple worms will attack any shriekers they encounter, and a hero in the form of a purple worm is [warned of shriekers](/wiki/Warned_of_monster_type "Warned of monster type").[\[4\]](#cite_note-wormfood-4)

*The following information pertains to an upcoming version ([NetHack 3.7.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.7.0 "NetHack 3.7.0")). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.*

Per [commit cf1c7251](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/commit/cf1c72514883f70856a8b98c654f52f2a9896794), [baby purple worms](/wiki/Baby_purple_worm "Baby purple worm") now appear in place of adult purple worms if a shrieker would summon the latter in an area where it is out of depth. Baby purple worms will also attack shriekers, and a hero in the form of a baby purple worm is also warned of shriekers.

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)

- [2 Strategy](#Strategy)

- [3 History](#History)

- [4 Origin](#Origin)

- [5 Messages](#Messages)

- [6 Variants](#Variants)

  - [6.1 SLASH'EM](#SLASH.27EM)
  - [6.2 dNetHack](#dNetHack)
  - [6.3 xNetHack](#xNetHack)
  - [6.4 SpliceHack](#SpliceHack)
  - [6.5 EvilHack](#EvilHack)
  - [6.6 SlashTHEM](#SlashTHEM)
  - [6.7 Hack'EM](#Hack.27EM)

- [7 Encyclopedia entry](#Encyclopedia_entry)

- [8 References](#References)

## Generation

Randomly generated shriekers are always created hostile.

Three shriekers are generated on the goal level of the [Caveman quest](/wiki/Caveman_quest "Caveman quest") at level creation.

## Strategy

Shriekers are not an active threat on their own, though their shrieking can be inconvenient and wake up monsters that a hero wants to leave undisturbed, and introduces the low-but-possible chance that an out-of-depth purple worm will generate and cause [YASD](/wiki/YASD "YASD"). Fortunately, shriekers are weak and move at minimum [speed](/wiki/Speed "Speed"), so they are generally easy to take out before the possibility can come up. [Ranged attacks](/wiki/Ranged_attack "Ranged attack") of any kind can help remove the possibility of a shriek summoning or awakening an unwanted monster, and shrieker corpses are a decent source of poison resistance for early heroes.

The most dangerous shriekers are likely to be the ones that [Cavepeople](/wiki/Cavepeople "Cavepeople") encounter on their quest, since they can potentially wake the [Chromatic Dragon](/wiki/Chromatic_Dragon "Chromatic Dragon") prematurely.

*The following information pertains to an upcoming version ([3.7.0](/wiki/3.7.0 "3.7.0")). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.*

Monsters can gain intrinsics from eating corpses, so a shrieker can be useful for giving poison resistance to a pet [pony](/wiki/Pony "Pony") (e.g. as a [Knight](/wiki/Knight "Knight")).

Baby purple worms are much slower and less dangerous than their adult forms, and a cunning hero can take advantage of one being summoned to gain a lot of experience early on, or even tame and raise the baby worm into an adult.

## History

The shrieker first appears in [NetHack 3.1.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.1.0 "NetHack 3.1.0").

## Origin

The shrieker originates from *[Dungeons & Dragons](/wiki/Dungeons_%26_Dragons "Dungeons & Dragons")*, where they debut in the 1st Edition *Monster Manual*. Shriekers are large and human-sized mushrooms that resemble [violet fungi](/wiki/Violet_fungi "Violet fungi"), but lack their poisons and tentacles, though they are immune to the fungi's poisons themselves; the 1st Edition material describes them as ambulatory, though later editions make them sessile. Shriekers are poisonous to most creatures as food, though they can be eaten by [purple worms](/wiki/Purple_worm "Purple worm"), hook horrors, shambling mounds, and medusae - this is the basis for the ability of shriekers in *NetHack* to summon purple worms, as well as the worm's ability to attack shriekers.[\[4\]](#cite_note-wormfood-4)

Shriekers live in dark underground environments such as the Underdark (the dwelling of the drow) and the homeworld of the illithids, and react to nearby motion or light with their namesake shriek. The sounds last between 5 and 15 seconds, and is meant to attract other beings to the area as prey: shriekers gain nourishment from breaking down nearby organic matter, and cannot attack on their own, so they are reliant on violet fungi to fatally poison the prey they attract. Inhabitants of the Underdark sometimes intentionally use shriekers as a form of intruder alarm.

The encyclopedia entry is an excerpt from [a series of campaign writeups](http://www.peldor.com/chapters.php?678) for *Advanced Dungeons and Dragons* games done by Thomas Miller. In the excerpt, an adventuring duo consisting of a human huntress and human warrior-monk attempts to infiltrate a lake-town inhabited by troglodytes. As the huntress Songa walks past a tall, skinny and mushroom-like fungus, it begins quivering before squealing loudly; Songa realizes the mushroom is a shrieker and kills it, but not before the troglodytes had already begun swarming to their position. While she and her partner Rillen escape the troglodytes, they eventually encounter a massive black worm - the worm itself is described as being reminiscent of the purple worm species.

## Messages

- \<The shrieker> shrieks.

  You are not [deaf](/wiki/Deaf "Deaf") and either chatted to a shrieker, or the shrieker got a turn while in melee range of an applicable target. This has gained a reputation as being one of the most memorable lines in *NetHack*.

- You smell mushrooms.

  A monster polymorphed into a shrieker.

## Variants

### SLASH'EM

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), shriekers are given [death resistance](/wiki/Death_resistance "Death resistance") and have a 9⁄10 chance of [reviving](/wiki/Reviving "Reviving") from their corpses like other non-[lichen](/wiki/Lichen "Lichen") fungi and molds.[\[5\]](#cite_note-5) A shrieker has an overall 1.85% chance of generating from a corpse that reach 51 turns of age, is not [acidic](/wiki/Acidic "Acidic"), and is not located within or on top of a square of [water](/wiki/Water "Water"), [ice](/wiki/Ice "Ice") or [lava](/wiki/Lava "Lava").[\[6\]](#cite_note-6)[\[7\]](#cite_note-7)[\[8\]](#cite_note-8)[\[9\]](#cite_note-9)

Shriekers can be generated in [fungus farms](/wiki/Fungus_farm "Fungus farm").

The shrieker shares its shrieking ability with the [squealer](/wiki/Squealer "Squealer") and [mobat](/wiki/Mobat "Mobat"): it can no longer summon purple worms, but has a 1⁄8 chance of summoning a random monster.[\[10\]](#cite_note-10)

### dNetHack

In [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack"), [notdNetHack](/wiki/NotdNetHack "NotdNetHack") and [notnotdNetHack](/wiki/NotnotdNetHack "NotnotdNetHack"), shriekers can revive from their own corpses.

### xNetHack

In [xNetHack](/wiki/XNetHack "XNetHack"), shriekers and other fungi and molds take extra damage from [copper](/wiki/Copper "Copper") items, and similar to SLASH'EM they can grow from old corpses, though with much lower odds.

### SpliceHack

In [SpliceHack](/wiki/SpliceHack "SpliceHack"), shriekers and other fungi and molds take extra damage from copper items, and similar to SLASH'EM they can grow from old corpses. A shrieker can [grow up](/wiki/Grow_up "Grow up") into a [screamer](/index.php?title=Screamer\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Screamer (page does not exist)").

### EvilHack

In [EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack"), tame monsters can gain intrinsics from eating corpses, so a shrieker can be useful for giving poison resistance to a pet [pony](/wiki/Pony "Pony") or other [herbivore](/wiki/Herbivore "Herbivore").

### SlashTHEM

In [SlashTHEM](/wiki/SlashTHEM "SlashTHEM"), shriekers are slightly less likely to generate from old corpses due to the addition of some new fungi and molds. All other SLASH'EM details apply.

### Hack'EM

In [Hack'EM](/wiki/Hack%27EM "Hack'EM"), shriekers and other fungi and molds take extra damage from copper items, and similar to SLASH'EM they can grow from old corpses. As in SpliceHack, a shrieker can grow up into a screamer.

Monsters eating corpses functions as in EvilHack, allowing the hero to feed shrieker corpses to applicable pets so they can potentially gain intrinsics.

## Encyclopedia entry

With a single, savage thrust of her spear, the warrior-woman impaled the fungus, silencing it. However, it was too late: the alarm had been raised \[...]  
Suddenly, a large, dark shape rose from the abyss before them, its fetid bulk looming overhead...The monster was some kind of great dark worm, but that was about all they were sure of.

\[ The Adventurers, Epic IV, by Thomas A. Miller ]

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [src/mon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 2861](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/mon.c#L2861)
2. [↑](#cite_ref-2) [src/mon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 2866](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/mon.c#L2866)
3. [↑](#cite_ref-3) [src/sounds.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 713](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/sounds.c#L713)
4. ↑ [4.0](#cite_ref-wormfood_4-0) [4.1](#cite_ref-wormfood_4-1) [src/mon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 1560](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/mon.c#L1560)
5. [↑](#cite_ref-5) [mkobj.c in SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2, line 764](/wiki/Source:SLASH%27EM_0.0.7E7F2/mkobj.c#line764 "Source:SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2/mkobj.c")
6. [↑](#cite_ref-6) [mkobj.c in SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2, line 765](/wiki/Source:SLASH%27EM_0.0.7E7F2/mkobj.c#line765 "Source:SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2/mkobj.c")
7. [↑](#cite_ref-7) [do.c in SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2, line 1685](/wiki/Source:SLASH%27EM_0.0.7E7F2/do.c#line1685 "Source:SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2/do.c")
8. [↑](#cite_ref-8) [mkobj.c in SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2, line 811](/wiki/Source:SLASH%27EM_0.0.7E7F2/mkobj.c#line811 "Source:SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2/mkobj.c")
9. [↑](#cite_ref-9) [do.c in SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2, line 1680](/wiki/Source:SLASH%27EM_0.0.7E7F2/do.c#line1680 "Source:SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2/do.c")
10. [↑](#cite_ref-10) [mon.c in SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2, line 2357](/wiki/Source:SLASH%27EM_0.0.7E7F2/mon.c#line2357 "Source:SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2/mon.c")

Shrieker

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search
F shrieker
Difficulty 2
Attacks None
F shrieker
Difficulty 2
Attacks

None

Base level 3
Base experience 28
Speed 1
Base AC 7
Base MR 0
Alignment 0 (neutral)
Frequency (by normal means) 1 (Very rare)
Genocidable Yes
Weight 100
Nutritional value 100
Size Small
Resistances Poison
Resistances conveyed Poison (20%)

A shrieker:

  • does not breathe.
  • cannot pick up items.
  • has no eyes.
  • has no limbs.
  • has no head.
  • is mindless.
  • does not eat. (*)
  • is neither male nor female.
  • is normally generated hostile.
Reference monst.c#line1327

A shrieker, F, is a type of monster that appears in NetHack. The shrieker is a type of fungus that is one of the few monsters to lack an attack of any kind, including a passive attack (even those that trigger on death, as with the gas spore).

In lieu of attacking, a shrieker will shriek intermittently when adjacent to the hero or to a monster attacking them, which can aggravate and wake up monsters and interrupts any occupation:[1] the shriek has an additional 1⁄10 chance of summoning a monster on the level, which has a 1⁄13 chance of being a purple worm and will otherwise be a random monster appropriate for the level.[2] Shrieking does not use up a turn.

Eating a shrieker corpse or tin has a 1⁄5 chance (20%) of granting poison resistance.

Chatting with a shrieker will also cause it to shriek, which aggravates monsters but cannot summon any.[3]

Purple worms will attack any shriekers they encounter, and a hero in the form of a purple worm is warned of shriekers.[4]

The following information pertains to an upcoming version (NetHack 3.7.0). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.

Per commit cf1c7251, baby purple worms now appear in place of adult purple worms if a shrieker would summon the latter in an area where it is out of depth. Baby purple worms will also attack shriekers, and a hero in the form of a baby purple worm is also warned of shriekers.

  • 2 Strategy
  • 3 History

  • 8 References

Generation

Randomly generated shriekers are always created hostile.

Three shriekers are generated on the goal level of the Caveman quest at level creation.

Strategy

Shriekers are not an active threat on their own, though their shrieking can be inconvenient and wake up monsters that a hero wants to leave undisturbed, and introduces the low-but-possible chance that an out-of-depth purple worm will generate and cause YASD. Fortunately, shriekers are weak and move at minimum speed, so they are generally easy to take out before the possibility can come up. Ranged attacks of any kind can help remove the possibility of a shriek summoning or awakening an unwanted monster, and shrieker corpses are a decent source of poison resistance for early heroes.

The most dangerous shriekers are likely to be the ones that Cavepeople encounter on their quest, since they can potentially wake the Chromatic Dragon prematurely.

The following information pertains to an upcoming version (3.7.0). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.

Monsters can gain intrinsics from eating corpses, so a shrieker can be useful for giving poison resistance to a pet pony (e.g. as a Knight).

Baby purple worms are much slower and less dangerous than their adult forms, and a cunning hero can take advantage of one being summoned to gain a lot of experience early on, or even tame and raise the baby worm into an adult.

History

The shrieker first appears in NetHack 3.1.0.

Origin

The shrieker originates from Dungeons & Dragons, where they debut in the 1st Edition Monster Manual. Shriekers are large and human-sized mushrooms that resemble violet fungi, but lack their poisons and tentacles, though they are immune to the fungi's poisons themselves; the 1st Edition material describes them as ambulatory, though later editions make them sessile. Shriekers are poisonous to most creatures as food, though they can be eaten by purple worms, hook horrors, shambling mounds, and medusae - this is the basis for the ability of shriekers in NetHack to summon purple worms, as well as the worm's ability to attack shriekers.[4]

Shriekers live in dark underground environments such as the Underdark (the dwelling of the drow) and the homeworld of the illithids, and react to nearby motion or light with their namesake shriek. The sounds last between 5 and 15 seconds, and is meant to attract other beings to the area as prey: shriekers gain nourishment from breaking down nearby organic matter, and cannot attack on their own, so they are reliant on violet fungi to fatally poison the prey they attract. Inhabitants of the Underdark sometimes intentionally use shriekers as a form of intruder alarm.

The encyclopedia entry is an excerpt from a series of campaign writeups for Advanced Dungeons and Dragons games done by Thomas Miller. In the excerpt, an adventuring duo consisting of a human huntress and human warrior-monk attempts to infiltrate a lake-town inhabited by troglodytes. As the huntress Songa walks past a tall, skinny and mushroom-like fungus, it begins quivering before squealing loudly; Songa realizes the mushroom is a shrieker and kills it, but not before the troglodytes had already begun swarming to their position. While she and her partner Rillen escape the troglodytes, they eventually encounter a massive black worm - the worm itself is described as being reminiscent of the purple worm species.

Messages

<The shrieker> shrieks.
You are not deaf and either chatted to a shrieker, or the shrieker got a turn while in melee range of an applicable target. This has gained a reputation as being one of the most memorable lines in NetHack.
You smell mushrooms.
A monster polymorphed into a shrieker.

Variants

SLASH'EM

In SLASH'EM, shriekers are given death resistance and have a 9⁄10 chance of reviving from their corpses like other non-lichen fungi and molds.[5] A shrieker has an overall 1.85% chance of generating from a corpse that reach 51 turns of age, is not acidic, and is not located within or on top of a square of water, ice or lava.[6][7][8][9]

Shriekers can be generated in fungus farms.

The shrieker shares its shrieking ability with the squealer and mobat: it can no longer summon purple worms, but has a 1⁄8 chance of summoning a random monster.[10]

dNetHack

In dNetHack, notdNetHack and notnotdNetHack, shriekers can revive from their own corpses.

xNetHack

In xNetHack, shriekers and other fungi and molds take extra damage from copper items, and similar to SLASH'EM they can grow from old corpses, though with much lower odds.

SpliceHack

In SpliceHack, shriekers and other fungi and molds take extra damage from copper items, and similar to SLASH'EM they can grow from old corpses. A shrieker can grow up into a screamer.

EvilHack

In EvilHack, tame monsters can gain intrinsics from eating corpses, so a shrieker can be useful for giving poison resistance to a pet pony or other herbivore.

SlashTHEM

In SlashTHEM, shriekers are slightly less likely to generate from old corpses due to the addition of some new fungi and molds. All other SLASH'EM details apply.

Hack'EM

In Hack'EM, shriekers and other fungi and molds take extra damage from copper items, and similar to SLASH'EM they can grow from old corpses. As in SpliceHack, a shrieker can grow up into a screamer.

Monsters eating corpses functions as in EvilHack, allowing the hero to feed shrieker corpses to applicable pets so they can potentially gain intrinsics.

Encyclopedia entry

With a single, savage thrust of her spear, the warrior-woman impaled the fungus, silencing it. However, it was too late: the alarm had been raised [...]
Suddenly, a large, dark shape rose from the abyss before them, its fetid bulk looming overhead...The monster was some kind of great dark worm, but that was about all they were sure of.

[ The Adventurers, Epic IV, by Thomas A. Miller ]

}}

A '''shrieker''', {{monsym|shrieker}}, is a type of [[monster]] that appears in ''[[NetHack]]''. The shrieker is a type of [[fungus]] that is one of the few monsters to lack an attack of any kind, including a [[passive attack]] (even those that trigger on death, as with the [[gas spore]]).

In lieu of attacking, a shrieker will shriek intermittently when adjacent to the [[hero]] or to a monster attacking them, which can [[aggravate]] and wake up monsters and interrupts any [[occupation]]:{{refsrc|src/mon.c|2861|nethack=3.6.7}} the shriek has an additional {{frac|10}} chance of summoning a monster on the level, which has a {{frac|13}} chance of being a [[purple worm]] and will otherwise be a random monster appropriate for the level.{{refsrc|src/mon.c|2866|nethack=3.6.7}} Shrieking does not use up a turn.

[[Eating]] a shrieker [[corpse]] or [[tin]] has a {{frac|5}} chance (20%) of granting [[poison resistance]].

[[Chatting]] with a shrieker will also cause it to shriek, which aggravates monsters but cannot summon any.{{refsrc|src/sounds.c|713|nethack=3.6.7}} 

Purple worms will attack any shriekers they encounter, and a hero in the form of a purple worm is [[Warned of monster type|warned of shriekers]].{{refsrc|src/mon.c|1560|version=NetHack 3.6.7|name="wormfood"}}

{{upcoming|NetHack 3.7.0|Per {{commit|cf1c72514883f70856a8b98c654f52f2a9896794}}, [[baby purple worm]]s now appear in place of adult purple worms if a shrieker would summon the latter in an area where it is out of depth. Baby purple worms will also attack shriekers, and a hero in the form of a baby purple worm is also warned of shriekers.}}

==Generation==
Randomly generated shriekers are always created hostile.

Three shriekers are generated on the goal level of the [[Caveman quest]] at level creation.

==Strategy==
Shriekers are not an active threat on their own, though their shrieking can be inconvenient and wake up monsters that a hero wants to leave undisturbed, and introduces the low-but-possible chance that an out-of-depth purple worm will generate and cause [[YASD]]. Fortunately, shriekers are weak and move at minimum [[speed]], so they are generally easy to take out before the possibility can come up. [[Ranged attack]]s of any kind can help remove the possibility of a shriek summoning or awakening an unwanted monster, and shrieker corpses are a decent source of poison resistance for early heroes.

The most dangerous shriekers are likely to be the ones that [[Cavepeople]] encounter on their quest, since they can potentially wake the [[Chromatic Dragon]] prematurely.

{{upcoming|3.7.0|Monsters can gain intrinsics from eating corpses, so a shrieker can be useful for giving poison resistance to a pet [[pony]] (e.g. as a [[Knight]]).

Baby purple worms are much slower and less dangerous than their adult forms, and a cunning hero can take advantage of one being summoned to gain a lot of experience early on, or even tame and raise the baby worm into an adult.}}

==History==
The shrieker first appears in [[NetHack 3.1.0]].

==Origin==
The shrieker originates from ''[[Dungeons & Dragons]]'', where they debut in the 1st Edition ''Monster Manual''. Shriekers are large and human-sized mushrooms that resemble [[violet fungi]], but lack their poisons and tentacles, though they are immune to the fungi's poisons themselves; the 1st Edition material describes them as ambulatory, though later editions make them sessile. Shriekers are poisonous to most creatures as food, though they can be eaten by [[purple worm]]s, hook horrors, shambling mounds, and medusae - this is the basis for the ability of shriekers in ''NetHack'' to summon purple worms, as well as the worm's ability to attack shriekers.<ref name="wormfood"/>

Shriekers live in dark underground environments such as the Underdark (the dwelling of the drow) and the homeworld of the illithids, and react to nearby motion or light with their namesake shriek. The sounds last between 5 and 15 seconds, and is meant to attract other beings to the area as prey: shriekers gain nourishment from breaking down nearby organic matter, and cannot attack on their own, so they are reliant on violet fungi to fatally poison the prey they attract. Inhabitants of the Underdark sometimes intentionally use shriekers as a form of intruder alarm.

The encyclopedia entry is an excerpt from [http://www.peldor.com/chapters.php?678 a series of campaign writeups] for ''Advanced Dungeons and Dragons'' games done by Thomas Miller. In the excerpt, an adventuring duo consisting of a human huntress and human warrior-monk attempts to infiltrate a lake-town inhabited by troglodytes. As the huntress Songa walks past a tall, skinny and mushroom-like fungus, it begins quivering before squealing loudly; Songa realizes the mushroom is a shrieker and kills it, but not before the troglodytes had already begun swarming to their position. While she and her partner Rillen escape the troglodytes, they eventually encounter a massive black worm - the worm itself is described as being reminiscent of the purple worm species.

==Messages==
{{message|<The shrieker> shrieks.|You are not [[deaf]] and either chatted to a shrieker, or the shrieker got a turn while in melee range of an applicable target. This has gained a reputation as being one of the most memorable lines in ''NetHack''.}}
{{message|You smell mushrooms.|A monster polymorphed into a shrieker.}}

==Variants==
===SLASH'EM===
In [[SLASH'EM]], shriekers are given [[death resistance]] and have a {{frac|9|10}} chance of [[reviving]] from their corpses like other non-[[lichen]] fungi and molds.{{refsrc|mkobj.c|764|version=SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2}} A shrieker has an overall 1.85% chance of generating from a corpse that reach 51 turns of age, is not [[acidic]], and is not located within or on top of a square of [[water]], [[ice]] or [[lava]].{{refsrc|mkobj.c|765|version=SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2}}{{refsrc|do.c|1685|version=SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2}}{{refsrc|mkobj.c|811|version=SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2}}{{refsrc|do.c|1680|version=SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2}}

Shriekers can be generated in [[fungus farm]]s.

The shrieker shares its shrieking ability with the [[squealer]] and [[mobat]]: it can no longer summon purple worms, but has a {{frac|8}} chance of summoning a random monster.{{refsrc|mon.c|2357|version=SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2}}

===dNetHack===
In [[dNetHack]], [[notdNetHack]] and [[notnotdNetHack]], shriekers can revive from their own corpses.

===xNetHack===
In [[xNetHack]], shriekers and other fungi and molds take extra damage from [[copper]] items, and similar to SLASH'EM they can grow from old corpses, though with much lower odds.

===SpliceHack===
In [[SpliceHack]], shriekers and other fungi and molds take extra damage from copper items, and similar to SLASH'EM they can grow from old corpses. A shrieker can [[grow up]] into a [[screamer]].

===EvilHack===
In [[EvilHack]], tame monsters can gain intrinsics from eating corpses, so a shrieker can be useful for giving poison resistance to a pet [[pony]] or other [[herbivore]].

===SlashTHEM===
In [[SlashTHEM]], shriekers are slightly less likely to generate from old corpses due to the addition of some new fungi and molds. All other SLASH'EM details apply.

===Hack'EM===
In [[Hack'EM]], shriekers and other fungi and molds take extra damage from copper items, and similar to SLASH'EM they can grow from old corpses. As in SpliceHack, a shrieker can grow up into a screamer.

Monsters eating corpses functions as in EvilHack, allowing the hero to feed shrieker corpses to applicable pets so they can potentially gain intrinsics.

==Encyclopedia entry==
{{encyclopedia|
With a single, savage thrust of her spear, the warrior-woman impaled the fungus, silencing it.  However, it was too late: the alarm had been raised [...]
Suddenly, a large, dark shape rose from the abyss before them, its fetid bulk looming overhead...The monster was some kind of great dark worm, but that was about all they were sure of.
|[ The Adventurers, Epic IV, by Thomas A. Miller ]
}}
